article.headline: Teslaâs stock shoots above $1,800 for first time after Wedbush analyst boosts target to 4th highest on the Street
article.body: Shares of Tesla Inc. rose Monday above the $1,800 level for the first time, after Wedbush analyst Dan Ives raised his target to be the fourth-highest on Wall Street, citing signs of accelerating demand in China. Tesla shares charged up 11.2% to a record close of $1,835.64, and have rocketed 33.6% in four sessions since the electric vehicle makerâs announced of a 5-for-1 stock split. That marks the eighth time Teslaâs stock has produced a rally of more than 30% in four sessions this year. Donât miss: Teslaâs stock run leads to 5-1 share split. Good timing, because Ives raised his âbase caseâ price target to $1,900 from $1,800. Of the 35 analysts surveyed by FactSet, Ivesâs target is now only below the $2,400 target of Piper Sandlerâs Alexander Potter, Oppenheimerâs Colin Ruschâs target of $2,209 and the $1,903.97 target of Everbright Securitiesâ Yu Jing Ni. Ivesâs target is well above the average target of $1,235.37, which is 32.7% below Mondayâs closing price. Meanwhile, Ivesâs âbull caseâ target is $2,500. âWe continue to believe [electric vehicle] demand in China is starting to accelerate in July/August with Tesla competing with a number of domestic and international competitors for market share with Giga 3 remaining the linchpin of success which remains the prize that [Chief Executive Elon] Musk and Tesla are laser focused on capturing,â Ives wrote in a research note. Giga 3 is the factory Tesla operates in Shanghai. âWe are seeing more leverage in the story now on the horizon out of Giga 3 along with some price cuts both in the US and China that could further stimulate demand as the macro starts to improve and the lockdown conditions ease globally,â Ives wrote. Despite Ivesâs bullish call, he still doesnât recommend investors buy the stock. He reiterated the neutral rating heâs had Tesla since April 25, 2019. At that time, his price target was $275. Ives expects Tesla to announce a number of new potential âgame changingâ battery developments at the companyâs Battery Day event, scheduled for Sept. 22, including a âmillion mileâ battery. âIn theory, this battery will support an electric vehicle for 1 million miles and be a major step forward when competing versus. traditional gasoline powered automotive competitors from both a [return on investment] and environmental perspective,â Ives wrote. Teslaâs stock has more than doubled (up 129.7%) over the past three months, while shares of China-based rival Nio Inc. NIO, +0.14% Â have skyrocketed fourfold (up 316.9%) and the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% Â has climbed 18.1%. Over the same time, Ivesâs price target has more than tripled, as his price target as of May 17 was $600. Teslaâs market capitalization has swelled to $342.02 billion. That is more than triple the combined market caps of auto makers General Motors Co. GM, -0.15% Â ($42.95 billion), Ford Motor Co. F, -1.36% Â ($$27.77 billion) and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles N.V. FCAU, -0.95% Â ($23.16 billion), and more than 50% above the market cap of Japanâs Toyota Motor Co. TM, -0.65% Â 7203, -0.95% Â ($221.12 billion). Meanwhile, General MotorsÂ shares jumped 7.7% to the highest close since June 8, after Deutsche Bank analyst Emmanuel Rosner pushed for the automaker to spin off its EV business into a separate entity. Rosner, who rates GM a buy, said he was adding the stock to Deutsche Bankâs short-term Catalyst Call Buy List. Rosner said he believes an EV spinoff would force the market to recognize its EV technology and upcoming vehicle lineup, âunlock considerable shareholder value,â give the new entity access to cheap capital and provide the new entity with the ability to attract high-caliber talent. GMâs stock has gained 32.6% over the past three months, but has dropped 18.0% year to date.
